text: Introduction

<extra_id_0> Sry <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> type HMG box ( <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is a member of the Sox transcription factor family characterized by the conserved high mobility group ( HMG ) domain , consisting of 79 amino acids involved in DNA recognition and binding [ 1 ] .

Sox transcription factors bind to the minor groove of DNA and cause a 70degrees-85degrees bend of the DNA that leads to local conformational changes [ 2 , 3 ] , while most other transcription factors target the major groove of DNA [ 4 ] .

Therefore , Sox proteins may perform part of their function as architectural proteins by organizing local chromatin structure and assembling other DNA - bound transcription factors into biologically active , sterically defined multiprotein complexes .

<extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has been reported to be able to act as either an activator or a repressor , depending on its interactors and its target promoter context [ 5 , 6 ] .
Intriguingly , <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> has also been shown to act as a general splicing factor that participates in pre - mRNA splicing [ 7 ] .

Depletion of <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in HeLa cell extracts blocked splicing of multiple substrates , and expression of the HMG domain of either <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> Sox9 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , or <extra_id_0> Sry <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the extracts restored splicing , indicating functional overlap of these proteins [ 7 ] .

Regardless of how <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> functions in regulating gene expression , previous studies have demonstrated that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is an important regulatory molecule that plays a role in the development of the central nervous system [ 8-11 ] , cartilage [ 6 , 12 , 13 ] , and muscle [ 14 , 15 ] .
A <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - null mutant mouse ( p100H ) has previously been identified in our laboratory [ 14 ] .
Mice homozygous for p100H show delayed growth , develop myopathy and arterioventricular heart block , and die within 2 wk after birth [ 14 ] .

The p100H mutant allele is associated with a Chromosome 7 inversion that disrupts both the <extra_id_0> p <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene and the <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene ( and no other gene within 50 , 000 nucleotides of the chromosomal breakpoints ) [ 14 ] .

Because the <extra_id_0> p <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene functions solely in pigmentation [ 16 ] , the <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcription factor is implicated in all other phenotypes .

Among the HMG box proteins distantly related to <extra_id_0> Sry <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( the first member identified of the Sox transcription factor family ) that similarly bind to the minor groove and bend DNA , but without sequence specificity , are the ubiquitously expressed <extra_id_0> HMG1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> HMG2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> proteins [ 17 ] .

Modulation of DNA structure by <extra_id_0> these <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and other HMG proteins can mediate long-range enhancer function on both DNA and chromatin-assembled genes by bringing together distant regions of DNA and associated factors .
Specifically , HMG proteins have been shown to modulate beta-globin genes [ 18-21 ] .

The mouse beta-globin genes <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> betah1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> beta-major <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> beta-minor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are clustered on Chromosome 7 and they are highly homologous to their human counterparts in organizational structure and function [ 22 ] .

High-level expression of <extra_id_0> these genes <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> requires a regulatory element , the locus control region that is characterized by a set of nuclease hypersensitive sites spread over 25 kb located 5 ' of the <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene [ 23 ] .
The beta-globin genes are expressed in a tissue - and development - specific fashion .

In mice , erythropoiesis originates in the embryonic yolk sac where primitive erythroid cells express <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> betah-1 globins <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 22 ] .

At 11.5 d post coitus ( dpc ) , erythropoiesis shifts to the fetal liver where definitive erythroid cells express adult <extra_id_0> beta globins <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> beta major <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> minor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) [ 22 ] .
The <extra_id_0> epsilony <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene is silenced in definitive erythroid cells .
The mechanism of silencing of its human counterpart , <extra_id_0> epsilon globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , has been studied extensively .

In definitive erythropoiesis , <extra_id_0> epsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is activated and silenced autonomously [ 24 , 25 ] , although in primitive erythropoiesis <extra_id_0> epsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> also appears to be regulated competitively [ 26 ] .

The <extra_id_0> gamma-globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to adult <extra_id_0> beta-globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> switch is controlled by promoter competition for the LCR [ 24 , 25 ] .

All the elements responsible for silencing the <extra_id_0> epsilon globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene are within the <extra_id_0> epsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene or in adjacent sequences [ 27 ] , suggesting that silencing is primarily gene autonomous .

Using promoter deletion analyses in transgenic mouse models and cell transfection assays , multiple DNA elements important to the silencing process have been previously identified in both the proximal and the distal <extra_id_0> epsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene promoter [ 27 ] .

Their corresponding transcription factors , such as <extra_id_0> GATA-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> YY-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> COUP-TF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> DRED <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> have been identified and shown to directly bind to these DNA elements ( as part of protein complexes ) to regulate <extra_id_0> epsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> silencing [ 27 ] .
Thus , it appears that the silencing of the <extra_id_0> epsilon <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene involves a complicated network of multiple cis elements and transacting proteins .

In addition to playing an important role in the development of the central nervous system [ 8-11 ] , cartilage [ 6 , 12 , 13 ] , and muscle [ 14 , 15 ] , it was shown that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is upregulated in long-term hematopoiesis stem cells ( LT-HSC ) compared with multipotent progenitors of adult mouse bone marrow lineage [ 28 ] .
In this study , we describe that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> also exerts pleiotropic effects on erythropoiesis .
These effects include delayed maturation of erythrocytes ( that normally enucleate prior to entering the bloodstream [ 27 ] ) and higher expression of embryonic globin genes .
The most extreme effect is the persistence of high expression of the embryonic <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .
Here we describe and characterize the effects of <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> on the <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> gene .

We show that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> binds to the proximal promoter of <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and represses <extra_id_0> its <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> transcription .

In wild-type ( WT ) mice , <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is not expressed in yolk sac blood islands , but is expressed in fetal liver , the opposite expression pattern of <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

In the absence of <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> epsilony globin <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is ectopically expressed in the fetal liver , demonstrating that <extra_id_0> Sox6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> functions in definitive erythropoiesis .
